00058 #define LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS 200
00059 /***************************************************************************/
00063 static int16_t _waitUntilSleep(HANDLE si114x_handle)
00064 {
00065   int8_t  retval = -1;
00066   uint8_t count = 0;
00067   // This loops until the Si114x is known to be in its sleep state
00068   // or if an i2c error occurs
00069   while(count < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00070   {
00071     retval = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_CHIP_STAT);
00072     if(retval == 1) break;
00073     if(retval <  0) return retval;
00074     count++;
00075     delay_1ms();
00076   }
00077   return 0;
00078 }
00081 /***************************************************************************/
00092 int16_t Si114xReset(HANDLE si114x_handle)
00093 {
00094   int32_t retval = 0;
00095 
00096   //
00097   // Do not access the Si114x earlier than 25 ms from power-up.
00098   // Uncomment the following lines if Si114xReset() is the first
00099   // instruction encountered, and if your system MCU boots up too
00100   // quickly.
00101   //
00102   delay_10ms();
00103   delay_10ms();
00104   delay_10ms();
00105 
00106   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_MEAS_RATE,  0x00);
00107   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_ALS_RATE,   0x00);
00108   retval+=Si114xPauseAll(si114x_handle);
00109 
00110   // The clearing of the registers could be redundant, but it is okay.
00111   // This is to make sure that these registers are cleared.
00112   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_MEAS_RATE,  0x00);
00113   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_IRQ_ENABLE, 0x00);
00114   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_IRQ_MODE1,  0x00);
00115   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_IRQ_MODE2,  0x00);
00116   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_INT_CFG  ,  0x00);
00117   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_IRQ_STATUS, 0xFF);
00118 
00119   // Perform the Reset Command
00120   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_COMMAND, 1);
00121 
00122   // Delay for 10 ms. This delay is needed to allow the Si114x
00123   // to perform internal reset sequence.
00124   delay_10ms();
00125 
00126   // Write Hardware Key
00127   retval+=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_HW_KEY, HW_KEY_VAL0);
00128 
00129   return retval;
00130 }
00131 
00133 /***************************************************************************/
00137 static int16_t _sendCmd(HANDLE si114x_handle, uint8_t command)
00138 {
00139   int16_t  response;
00140   int8_t   retval;
00141   uint8_t  count = 0;
00142 
00143   // Get the response register contents
00144   response = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00145   if(response < 0)
00146     return response;
00147 
00148   // Double-check the response register is consistent
00149   while(count < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00150   {
00151     if((retval=_waitUntilSleep(si114x_handle)) != 0) return retval;
00152 
00153     if(command==0) break; // Skip if the command is NOP
00154 
00155     retval=Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00156     if(retval==response) break;
00157     else if(retval<0) return retval;
00158     else response = retval;
00159     count++;
00160   }
00161 
00162   // Send the Command
00163   if((retval=Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_COMMAND, command)) !=0)
00164     return retval;
00165 
00166   count = 0;
00167   // Expect a change in the response register
00168   while(count < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00169   {
00170     if(command==0) break; // Skip if the command is NOP
00171 
00172     retval= Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00173     if(retval != response) break;
00174     else if(retval<0) return retval;
00175     count++;
00176     delay_1ms();
00177   }
00178   return 0;
00179 }
00182 /***************************************************************************/
00190 int16_t Si114xNop(HANDLE si114x_handle)
00191 {
00192   return _sendCmd(si114x_handle,0x00);
00193 }

00267 int16_t Si114xParamRead(HANDLE si114x_handle, uint8_t address)
00268 {
00269   // returns Parameter[address]
00270   int16_t retval;
00271   uint8_t cmd = 0x80 + (address & 0x1F);
00272 
00273   retval=_sendCmd(si114x_handle, cmd);
00274   if( retval != 0 ) return retval;
00275 
00276   retval = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_PARAM_RD);
00277   return retval;
00278 }
00279 
00280 /***************************************************************************/
00300 int16_t Si114xParamSet(HANDLE si114x_handle, uint8_t address, uint8_t value)
00301 {
00302   int16_t retval;
00303   uint8_t buffer[2];
00304   int16_t response_stored;
00305   int16_t response;
00306 
00307   if((retval = _waitUntilSleep(si114x_handle))!=0) return retval;
00308 
00309   response_stored = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00310 
00311   buffer[0]= value;
00312   buffer[1]= 0xA0 + (address & 0x1F);
00313 
00314   retval=Si114xBlockWrite(si114x_handle, REG_PARAM_WR, 2, ( uint8_t* ) buffer);
00315   if(retval != 0) return retval;
00316 
00317   // Wait for command to finish
00318   response = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00319   while(response == response_stored )
00320   {
00321     response = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00322     if (response == response_stored)
00323     {
00324       delay_1ms();
00325     }
00326   }
00327 
00328   if(retval < 0)
00329     return retval;
00330   else
00331     return 0;
00332 }

00335 /***************************************************************************/
00339 static int16_t _PsAlsPause (HANDLE si114x_handle)
00340 {
00341   return _sendCmd(si114x_handle,0x0B);
00342 }
00345 /***************************************************************************/
00355 int16_t Si114xPauseAll(HANDLE si114x_handle)
00356 {
00357   uint8_t countA, countB;
00358   int8_t  retval;
00359 
00360 
00361   //  After a RESET, if the Si114x receives a command (including NOP) before the
00362   //  Si114x has gone to sleep, the chip hangs. This first while loop avoids
00363   //  this.  The reading of the REG_CHIPSTAT does not disturb the internal MCU.
00364   //
00365 
00366    retval = 0; //initialize data so that we guarantee to enter the loop
00367    while(retval != 0x01)
00368    {
00369      retval = Si114xReadFromRegister( si114x_handle, REG_CHIP_STAT);
00370      if (retval != 0x01)
00371      {
00372        delay_1ms();
00373      }
00374    }
00375 
00376   countA = 0;
00377   while(countA < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00378   {
00379     countB = 0;
00380     // Keep sending nops until the response is zero
00381     while(countB < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00382     {
00383       retval = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00384       if( retval == 0 )
00385           break;
00386       else
00387       {
00388         // Send the NOP Command to clear any error...we cannot use Si114xNop()
00389         // because it first checks if REG_RESPONSE < 0 and if so it does not
00390         // perform the cmd. Since we have a saturation REG_RESPONSE will be <0
00391         Si114xWriteToRegister(si114x_handle, REG_COMMAND, 0x00);
00392       }
00393       countB++;
00394       delay_1ms();
00395     }
00396 
00397     // Pause the device
00398     _PsAlsPause(si114x_handle);
00399 
00400     countB = 0;
00401     // Wait for response
00402     while(countB < LOOP_TIMEOUT_MS)
00403     {
00404       retval = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00405       if( retval !=0 )
00406         break;
00407       countB++;
00408       delay_1ms();
00409     }
00410 
00411     // When the PsAlsPause() response is good, we expect it to be a '1'.
00412     retval = Si114xReadFromRegister(si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE);
00413     if( retval == 1 )
00414       break;  // otherwise, start over.
00415     countA++;
00416   }
00417   return 0;
00418 }
00419 
00420 /******************************************************************************/
00421 /***********   INCLUDE_SI114x_COMPRESS_CODE  **********************************/
00422 /******************************************************************************/
00423 #if( INCLUDE_SI114X_COMPRESS_CODE == 1 )
00424 //
00425 // The goal of uncompress is to arrive at a 16-bit value, when the input is a
00426 // single byte of information.
00427 //
00428 // The approach taken here is to reuse the floating point concept, but apply it
00429 // to this. Just as it is possible to store relatively large numbers using an
00430 // IEEE 754 representation of a 32 bit value, we make use of a similar concept.
00431 //
00432 // In IEEE 754 representation, there consists of concept of a signed exponent,
00433 // and a signed significand. The signed exponent allows representation of
00434 // values between 2^127 to 2^-128. The signficand is also signed.
00435 //
00436 // The term 'significand' is the integer bit plus the fraction. The 'fraction'
00437 // is the fractional part of the significand.
00438 //
00439 //              IEEE Single Precision Format
00440 //
00441 //     |  b31   |   b30 to  b23   |  bit22 to bit0  |
00442 //     |  Sign  | Signed Exponent |   Fraction      |
00443 //
00444 // In what we need, we do not need signed exponents nor do we need signed
00445 // significands. So, we use an unsigned exponent representation and an unsigned
00446 // significand.
00447 //
00448 // uncompress takes an input byte and interprets the first 4 bits as an
00449 // exponent, and the last 4 bits as a fraction, with an implicit integer bit
00450 //
00451 // The mathematical representation is similar to the concept for floating point
00452 // numbers. First off, the bit field 7:4 is the Exponent, and the bit field 3:0
00453 // is the fractional part of the significand.
00454 //
00455 //
00456 //      | b7 b6 b5 b4 | b3 b2 b1 b0 |
00457 //      |   unsigned  |             |
00458 //      |   Exponent  |  Fraction   |
00459 //
00460 // The number representation is:
00461 //
00462 //      ( 2 ^ Exponent ) * 1.Fraction
00463 //
00464 // Note the 'implicit integer bit'. Normally, the hidden integer is 1. However,
00465 // there is an exception. If the Exponent is zero, the representation
00466 // becomes the following:
00467 //
00468 //      ( 2 ^ 0 ) * 0.Fraction
00469 //
00470 // This is the concept called the 'denormalized number' identical to the IEEE
00471 // 754 representation of floating point numbers. Concept isn't new... this
00472 // allows us to represent the value 0.
00473 //
00474 // Let's go through one example...
00475 //
00476 // Let's say input is 0x9A.
00477 //
00478 //     Exponent = 9
00479 //     Fraction = A
00480 //
00481 // Since the Exponent is non-zero, the number representation is:
00482 //
00483 //     2 ^ 9 * (1.1010)
00484 //
00485 // So, we take 1.1010 and shift left by 9 positions. It is best illustrated in
00486 // binary...
00487 //
00488 //    1.1010 << 9 = 1 1010 00000 = 0x340
00489 //
00490 // The main advantage is that it allows a very large range dynamic range
00491 // to be represented in 8 bits. The largest number that can be represented
00492 // is 0xFF, and this translates to:
00493 //
00494 //     2 ^ 15 * 1.1111
00495 //
00496 //     1.1111 << 15 = 1111 1000 0000 0000 = 0xF800
00497 //
00498 // When the exponent is less than 4, notice that the fraction bits are
00499 // truncated. What this means is that there can be multiple ways of getting an
00500 // output from 0 to
00501 // the value '0x0000' to 0x000F
00502 //
00503 // To illustrate the case where exponents are less than 4:
00504 //      Input     Output
00505 //      00        0000
00506 //      02        0000
00507 //      08        0001
00508 //      0A        0001
00509 //      10        0002
00510 //      14        0002
00511 //      18        0003
00512 //      1A        0003
00513 //      20        0004
00514 //      24        0005
00515 //      28        0006
00516 //      2c        0007
00517 //      30        0008
00518 //      32        0009
00519 //      34        000a
00520 //      36        000b
00521 //      38        000c
00522 //      3c        000e
00523 //      3e        000f
00524 //
00525 // At exponent of 4 or greater, the fraction bits are no longer being thrown
00526 // away, so, we now have linear values
00527 //      40        0010
00528 //      41        0011
00529 //      42        0012
00530 //      43        0013
00531 //      44        0014
00532 //
00533 // But alas, once the exponent is greater than 4, we now stuff the lower
00534 // fractional bits with zero, and we begin to skip numbers...
00535 //      50        0020
00536 //      51        0022
00537 //      52        0024
00538 //      53        0026
00539 //      54        0028
00540 //
00541 // Well...strictly speaking, the IEEE format treats the largest possible
00542 // exponent as 'infinity' or NAN. Let's not go there... Denorm concept is useful
00543 // for us since it allows us to represent zero. However, infinity or NAN
00544 // concepts are not useful for us.
00545 //
00546 
00547 /***************************************************************************/
00557 uint16_t Uncompress(uint8_t input) // It is important for the input to be
00558                                    // unsigned 8-bit.
00559 {
00560   uint16_t output   = 0;
00561   uint8_t  exponent = 0;
00562 
00563   // Handle denorm case where exponent is zero. In this case, we are
00564   // evaluating the value with the integer bit is zero (0.F). So, we round up
00565   // if the fraction represents a value of 1/2 or greater. Since the fraction
00566   // is 4 bits, an input of less than 8/16 is less than half. If less than
00567   // half, return zero. Otherwise, we know that we will return a 1 later.
00568   //
00569   if( input < 8 ) return 0;
00570 
00571   //
00572   // At this point, the exponent is non-zero, so, put in the implicit
00573   // fraction. Note that when we get the input, it comes in already shifted
00574   // by 4. So, we are dealing with a value already 4 times larger than the
00575   // actual starting point.
00576   //
00577   // Never fear... we just make an adjustment to the exponent and shift
00578   // left/right accordingly. The result will be the same as the floating
00579   // point concept described above.
00580   //
00581 
00582   exponent = (input & 0xF0 ) >> 4;      // extracts the exponent
00583   output = 0x10  | (input & 0x0F);      // extracts the fraction and adds
00584                                         // in the implicit integer
00585 
00586   if( exponent >= 4 ) return ( output << (exponent-4) );
00587   return( output >> (4-exponent) );
00588 }
00589 
00590 
00591 // --------------------------------------------------------------------
00592 // What if someone wants to do the inverse function?
00593 //
00594 // Let's say we want to figure out what byte value best represents the number
00595 // of 32 KHz timer ticks for 500 ms.
00596 //
00597 // We start of by knowing how many 32 KHz cycles are in that given time period.
00598 // Let's say that we want to have the RTC wake up every 500 ms.
00599 //
00600 //     500 ms * 32 KHz = 16000 cycles
00601 //
00602 // Then, we take the calculator, and find out what 64 looks like from a binary
00603 // value viewpoint. Using a hex calculator, we see that:
00604 //
00605 //     16000 = 11111010000000
00606 //
00607 //     ... in floating point representation...
00608 //
00609 //           = 11111010000000.00000
00610 //
00611 // The next step is to normalize the value. Normalizing the value means that
00612 // we represent the value in 1.F format. We do this by moving the decimal value
00613 // left until we get the 1.F representation. The number of times we move the
00614 // decimal point left is the exponent. Since we need to move the decimal point
00615 // left before we get to the 1.F represenation...
00616 //
00617 //     16000 = 2^13 * 1.1111010000000
00618 //
00619 // The exponent is therefore 13, and the digits to the right hand side of the
00620 // decimal point is the fraction. What we need is the the first four fractional
00621 // bits. The first four fraction bits is 1111. We truncate the rest,
00622 // unfortunately.
00623 //
00624 // Therefore, the nearest byte representation for 500 ms is 0xDF
00625 //
00626 // Notice that if you plugged in 0xDF into this uncompress function, you will
00627 // get 496 ms. The reason we didn't quite get 500 ms is that we had to throw
00628 // away the 6th fractional bit.
00629 //
00630 // Anyway, this leads us to the following function. This function takes in a
00631 // 16-bit value and compresses it.
00632 
00633 /***************************************************************************/
00645 uint8_t Compress(uint16_t input) // input should be a 16-bit unsigned value
00646 {
00647   uint32_t tmp         = 0;
00648   uint32_t exponent    = 0;
00649   uint32_t significand = 0;
00650 
00651   if(input==0)
00652     return 0;
00653 
00654 
00655   // handle denorm cases
00656   // There are multiple answers to 0x0000 and 0x0001 input due to rounding
00657   // error introduced throught the gradual underflow
00658   //     Answer for 0x0000 is from 0x00 to 0x07
00659   //     Answer for 0x0001 is from 0x08 to 0x0F
00660   // We will just 'pick one' answer.
00661   if(input == 0x0000) return 0x00;
00662   if(input == 0x0001) return 0x08;
00663 
00664   // Now we have the denorm cases out of the way, the exponent should be at
00665   // least one at this point.
00666   exponent = 0;
00667   tmp = input;
00668   while(1)
00669   {
00670     tmp >>= 1;  // Shift until there is only the integer in the lease
00671                 //  significant position
00672     exponent += 1;
00673     if(tmp == 1)
00674     {
00675       break;  // the integer bit has been found. Stop.
00676     }
00677   }
00678 
00679   // Once exponent is found, look for the four fractional bits.
00680   //
00681   // If the exponent is between 1 to 4, we do not need to do any kind of
00682   // fractional rounding. Take care of those cases first
00683 
00684   if(exponent < 5) // shift left to align the significant and return the
00685                     // result
00686   {
00687     significand = ( input << (4 - exponent) ) ;
00688     return ( (exponent << 4) | (significand & 0xF));
00689   }
00690 
00691   // At this point, we need to calculate the fraction.
00692   //
00693   // Easiest way is to align the value so that we have the integer and
00694   // fraction bits at a known bit position.
00695   //
00696   // We then round the signficand to the nearest four fractional bits. To do
00697   // so, it is best that we also look at the 5th fractional bit and update
00698   // the 4th fractional bit as necessary. During rounding, it is possible for
00699   // a carry to occur. If this happens, simply add one to the exponent, and
00700   // shift the signficand by one to get to the same bit positioning.
00701 
00702   significand = input >> (exponent - 5);
00703 
00704   //
00705   // After the shift, the significand looks like this since we shift the
00706   // value by 5 less than the exponent. This is what we expect at this point:
00707   //
00708   // bit[15:6]     bit5  bit4  bit3  bit2  bit1  bit0
00709   //
00710   //   zeroes       1    2^-1  2^-2  2^-3  2^-4  2^-5
00711   //
00712   //                ^    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
00713   //               int            fraction
00714   //
00715 
00716   if(significand & 1) // Check if we need to round up
00717   {
00718     significand += 2;   // Increment the 4th fraction (in bit1 position)
00719 
00720     // We then check if a carry occurred due to the addition. If a carry
00721     // did occur, it would have bumped up the number such that bit6 would
00722     // be set. Bit6 is 0x0040.
00723     if(significand & 0x0040)         // Check for a carry
00724     {
00725       exponent += 1;                // A carry occurred. Increment the exponent
00726       significand >>= 1;            // shift the signficand right by one
00727     }
00728   }
00729 
00730   // Rounding is done... Encode value and return.
00731   return ( (exponent << 4) | ( (significand >> 1) & 0xF ) );
00732 }
00733 #endif // INCLUDE_SI114X_COMPRESS_CODE

00773 /***************************************************************************/
00777 struct cal_ref_t
00778 {
00779   uint32_t sirpd_adchi_irled; 
00780   uint32_t sirpd_adclo_irled; 
00781   uint32_t sirpd_adclo_whled; 
00782   uint32_t vispd_adchi_whled;

00789 /***************************************************************************/
00793 struct cal_ref_t calref[2] =
00794 {
00795   {
00796     FLT_TO_FX20( 4.021290),  // sirpd_adchi_irled
00797     FLT_TO_FX20(57.528500),  // sirpd_adclo_irled
00798     FLT_TO_FX20( 2.690010),  // sirpd_adclo_whled
00799     FLT_TO_FX20( 0.042903),  // vispd_adchi_whled
00800     FLT_TO_FX20( 0.633435),  // vispd_adclo_whled
00801     FLT_TO_FX20(23.902900),  // lirpd_adchi_irled
00802     FLT_TO_FX20(56.889300),  // ledi_65ma
00803     {0x7B, 0x6B, 0x01, 0x00} // default ucoef
00804   },
00805   {
00806     FLT_TO_FX20( 2.325484),  // sirpd_adchi_irled
00807     FLT_TO_FX20(33.541500),  // sirpd_adclo_irled
00808     FLT_TO_FX20( 1.693750),  // sirpd_adclo_whled
00809     FLT_TO_FX20( 0.026775),  // vispd_adchi_whled
00810     FLT_TO_FX20( 0.398443),  // vispd_adclo_whled
00811     FLT_TO_FX20(12.190900),  // lirpd_adchi_irled
00812     FLT_TO_FX20(56.558200),  // ledi_65ma
00813     {0xdb, 0x8f, 0x01, 0x00} // default ucoef
00814   }
00815 };
00816 
00818 /***************************************************************************/
00823 static uint32_t decode(uint32_t input)
00824 {
00825   int32_t  exponent, exponent_bias9;
00826   uint32_t mantissa;
00827 
00828   if(input==0) return 0.0;
00829 
00830   exponent_bias9 = (input & 0x0f00) >> 8;
00831   exponent       = exponent_bias9 - 9;
00832 
00833   mantissa       = input & 0x00ff; // fraction
00834   mantissa       |=        0x0100; // add in integer
00835 
00836   // representation in 12 bit integer, 20 bit fraction
00837   mantissa       = mantissa << (12+exponent);
00838   return mantissa;
00839 }
00843 /***************************************************************************/
00850 static uint32_t collect(uint8_t* buffer,
00851                         uint8_t msb_addr,
00852                         uint8_t lsb_addr,
00853                         uint8_t alignment)
00854 {
00855   uint16_t value;
00856   uint8_t  msb_ind = msb_addr - 0x22;
00857   uint8_t  lsb_ind = lsb_addr - 0x22;
00858 
00859   if(alignment == 0)
00860   {
00861     value =  buffer[msb_ind]<<4;
00862     value += buffer[lsb_ind]>>4;
00863   }
00864   else
00865   {
00866     value =  buffer[msb_ind]<<8;
00867     value += buffer[lsb_ind];
00868     value &= 0x0fff;
00869   }
00870 
00871   if(   ( value == 0x0fff )
00872      || ( value == 0x0000 ) ) return FX20_BAD_VALUE;
00873   else return decode( value );
00874 }
00878 /***************************************************************************/
00884 static void shift_left(uint32_t* value_p, int8_t shift)
00885 {
00886   if(shift > 0)
00887     *value_p = *value_p<<shift ;
00888   else
00889     *value_p = *value_p>>(-shift) ;
00890 }
00894 #define ALIGN_LEFT   1
00895 #define ALIGN_RIGHT -1
00896 /***************************************************************************/
00902 static int8_t align( uint32_t* value_p, int8_t direction )
00903 {
00904   int8_t   local_shift, shift ;
00905   uint32_t mask;
00906 
00907   // Check invalid value_p and *value_p, return without shifting if bad.
00908   if( value_p  == NULL )  return 0;
00909   if( *value_p == 0 )     return 0;
00910 
00911   // Make sure direction is valid
00912   switch( direction )
00913   {
00914     case ALIGN_LEFT:
00915       local_shift =  1 ;
00916       mask  = 0x80000000L;
00917       break;
00918 
00919     case ALIGN_RIGHT:
00920       local_shift = -1 ;
00921       mask  = 0x00000001L;
00922       break;
00923 
00924     default:
00925       // Invalid direction, return without shifting
00926       return 0;
00927   }
00928 
00929   shift = 0;
00930   while(1)
00931   {
00932     if(*value_p & mask ) break;
00933     shift++;
00934     shift_left( value_p, local_shift );
00935   }
00936   return shift;
00937 }
00940 /***************************************************************************/
00946 #define FORCE_ROUND_16 1
00947 
00949 /***************************************************************************/
00959 static void fx20_round
00960 (
00961   uint32_t *value_p
00962   #if !FORCE_ROUND_16
00963   , int8_t round
00964   #endif
00965 )
00966 {
00967   int8_t  shift;
00968 
00969   #if FORCE_ROUND_16
00970     // Use the following to force round = 16
00971     uint32_t mask1  = 0xffff8000;
00972     uint32_t mask2  = 0xffff0000;
00973     uint32_t lsb    = 0x00008000;
00974   #else
00975     // Use the following if you want to routine to be
00976     // capable of rounding to something other than 16.
00977     uint32_t mask1  = ((2<<(round))-1)<<(31-(round));
00978     uint32_t mask2  = ((2<<(round-1))-1)<<(31-(round-1));
00979     uint32_t lsb    = mask1-mask2;
00980   #endif
00981 
00982   shift = align( value_p, ALIGN_LEFT );
00983   if( ( (*value_p)&mask1 ) == mask1 )
00984   {
00985     *value_p = 0x80000000;
00986     shift -= 1;
00987   }
00988   else
00989   {
00990     *value_p += lsb;
00991     *value_p &= mask2;
00992   }
00993 
00994   shift_left( value_p, -shift );
00995 }
00998 /***************************************************************************/
01003 struct operand_t
01004 {
01005   uint32_t op1;  
01006   uint32_t op2;  
01007 };
01008 
01010 /***************************************************************************/
01014 static uint32_t fx20_divide( struct operand_t* operand_p )
01015 {
01016   int8_t    numerator_sh=0, denominator_sh=0;
01017   uint32_t  result;
01018   uint32_t* numerator_p;
01019   uint32_t* denominator_p;
01020 
01021   if( operand_p == NULL ) return FX20_BAD_VALUE;
01022 
01023   numerator_p   = &operand_p->op1;
01024   denominator_p = &operand_p->op2;
01025 
01026   if(   (*numerator_p   == FX20_BAD_VALUE)
01027       || (*denominator_p == FX20_BAD_VALUE)
01028       || (*denominator_p == 0             ) ) return FX20_BAD_VALUE;
01029 
01030   fx20_round  ( numerator_p   );
01031   fx20_round  ( denominator_p );
01032   numerator_sh   = align ( numerator_p,   ALIGN_LEFT  );
01033   denominator_sh = align ( denominator_p, ALIGN_RIGHT );
01034 
01035   result = *numerator_p / ( (uint16_t)(*denominator_p) );
01036   shift_left( &result , 20-numerator_sh-denominator_sh );
01037 
01038   return result;
01039 }
01043 /***************************************************************************/
01047 static uint32_t fx20_multiply( struct operand_t* operand_p )
01048 {
01049   uint32_t  result;
01050   int8_t    val1_sh, val2_sh;
01051   uint32_t* val1_p;
01052   uint32_t* val2_p;
01053 
01054   if( operand_p == NULL ) return FX20_BAD_VALUE;
01055 
01056   val1_p = &(operand_p->op1);
01057   val2_p = &(operand_p->op2);
01058 
01059   fx20_round( val1_p );
01060   fx20_round( val2_p );
01061 
01062   val1_sh = align( val1_p, ALIGN_RIGHT );
01063   val2_sh = align( val2_p, ALIGN_RIGHT );
01064 
01065 
01066   result = (uint32_t)( ( (uint32_t)(*val1_p) ) * ( (uint32_t)(*val2_p) ) );
01067   shift_left( &result, -20+val1_sh+val2_sh );
01068 
01069   return result;
01070 }
01074 /***************************************************************************/
01081 static int16_t find_cal_index( uint8_t* buffer )
01082 {
01083   int16_t index;
01084   uint8_t size;
01085 
01086   // buffer[12] is the LSB, buffer[13] is the MSB
01087   index = ( int16_t )( buffer[12] + ( (uint16_t)( buffer[13] ) << 8 ) );
01088 
01089   switch( index )
01090   {
01091     case -1:
01092       index = 0;
01093       break;
01094     case -2:
01095       index = 0;
01096       break;
01097     case -3:
01098       index = 1;
01099     default:
01100       index = -(4+index) ;
01101   }
01102 
01103   size = sizeof(calref)/sizeof(calref[0]);
01104 
01105   if( index < size )
01106   {
01107     return  index;
01108   }
01109   else
01110   {
01111     return -1;
01112   }
01113 }
01117 /***************************************************************************/
01121 static uint32_t vispd_correction(uint8_t* buffer)
01122 {
01123 
01124   struct operand_t op;
01125   uint32_t         result;
01126   int16_t          index = find_cal_index( buffer );
01127 
01128   if( index < 0 ) result = FX20_ONE;
01129 
01130   op.op1 = calref[ index ].vispd_adclo_whled;
01131   op.op2 = VISPD_ADCLO_WHLED;
01132   result = fx20_divide( &op );
01133 
01134   if( result == FX20_BAD_VALUE ) result = FX20_ONE;
01135 
01136   return result;
01137 }
01141 /***************************************************************************/
01145 static uint32_t irpd_correction(uint8_t* buffer)
01146 {
01147   struct operand_t op;
01148   uint32_t         result;
01149   int16_t          index = find_cal_index( buffer );
01150 
01151   if( index < 0 ) result = FX20_ONE;
01152 
01153   // op.op1 = SIRPD_ADCLO_IRLED_REF; op.op2 = SIRPD_ADCLO_IRLED;
01154   op.op1 = calref[ index ].sirpd_adclo_irled;
01155   op.op2 = SIRPD_ADCLO_IRLED;
01156   result = fx20_divide( &op );
01157 
01158   if( result == FX20_BAD_VALUE ) result = FX20_ONE;
01159 
01160   return result;
01161 }
01165 /***************************************************************************/
01171 static uint32_t adcrange_ratio(uint8_t* buffer)
01172 {
01173   struct operand_t op;
01174   uint32_t         result;
01175 
01176   op.op1 = SIRPD_ADCLO_IRLED  ; op.op2 = SIRPD_ADCHI_IRLED  ;
01177   result = fx20_divide( &op );
01178 
01179   if( result == FX20_BAD_VALUE ) result = FLT_TO_FX20( 14.5 );
01180 
01181   return result;
01182 }
01186 /***************************************************************************/
01191 static uint32_t irsize_ratio(uint8_t* buffer)
01192 {
01193   struct operand_t op;
01194   uint32_t         result;
01195 
01196   op.op1 = LIRPD_ADCHI_IRLED  ; op.op2 = SIRPD_ADCHI_IRLED  ;
01197 
01198   result = fx20_divide( &op );
01199 
01200   if( result == FX20_BAD_VALUE ) result = FLT_TO_FX20(  6.0 );
01201 
01202   return  result;
01203 }
01207 /***************************************************************************/
01212 static uint32_t ledi_ratio(uint8_t* buffer)
01213 {
01214 
01215   struct operand_t op;
01216   uint32_t         result;
01217   int16_t          index;
01218 
01219   index = find_cal_index( buffer );
01220 
01221   if( index < 0 ) result = FX20_ONE;
01222 
01223   // op.op1 = LED_DRV65_REF; op.op2 = LED_DRV65;
01224   op.op1 = calref[ index ].ledi_65ma;
01225   op.op2 = LED_DRV65;
01226   result = fx20_divide( &op );
01227 
01228   if( result == FX20_BAD_VALUE ) result = FX20_ONE;
01229 
01230   return result;
01231 }
01235 /***************************************************************************/
01241 static int16_t si114x_get_cal_index( HANDLE si114x_handle, uint8_t* buffer )
01242 {
01243   int16_t retval;
01244   uint8_t response;
01245 
01246   if( ( si114x_handle == NULL ) || ( buffer == NULL ) )
01247     return -1;
01248 
01249   // Check to make sure that the device is ready to receive commands
01250   do
01251   {
01252     retval = Si114xNop( si114x_handle );
01253     if( retval != 0 ) return -1;
01254 
01255 
01256     response = Si114xReadFromRegister( si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE );
01257     if (response != 0)
01258     {
01259       delay_1ms();
01260     }
01261   } while( response != 0 );
01262 
01263   // Retrieve the index
01264   retval = Si114xWriteToRegister( si114x_handle, REG_COMMAND, 0x11 );
01265   _waitUntilSleep(si114x_handle);
01266 
01267   if( retval != 0 ) return -1;
01268 
01269   retval = Si114xBlockRead( si114x_handle, REG_PS1_DATA0, 2, &(buffer[12]) );
01270   if( retval != 0 ) return -1;
01271 
01272   return 0;
01273 }
01276 /***************************************************************************/
01319 /*
01320  * Side-effects:
01321  *     - Writes 0x11 to command reg to retrieve factory calibration values in
01322  *       buffer[0] to buffer[11]
01323  *
01324  *     - Calls the various helper functions such as vispd_correction()
01325  *       irpd_correction, to populate the SI114X_CAL_S structure
01326  *
01327  *     - Writes 0x12 to command reg to retrieve factory cal_index to
01328  *       buffer[12] to buffer[13]
01329  ******************************************************************************/
01330 int16_t si114x_get_calibration( HANDLE        si114x_handle,
01331                                 SI114X_CAL_S* si114x_cal,
01332                                 uint8_t       security)
01333 {
01334   uint8_t buffer[14];
01335   int16_t retval = 0;
01336   uint8_t response;
01337 
01338   if( si114x_handle == NULL ) { retval = -4; goto error_exit; }
01339 
01340   if( si114x_cal    == NULL ) { retval = -4; goto error_exit; }
01341 
01342   // if requested, check to make sure the interface registers are zero
01343   // as an indication of a device that has not started any autonomous
01344   // operation
01345   if( security == 1 )
01346   {
01347     int8_t i;
01348 
01349     retval = Si114xBlockRead( si114x_handle, REG_ALS_VIS_DATA0, 12, buffer );
01350     if( retval != 0 ) { retval = -2; goto error_exit; }
01351 
01352     for( i=0; i<12; i++)
01353     {
01354         if( buffer[i] != 0 ) { retval = -1; goto error_exit; }
01355     }
01356 
01357     DEBUG_PRINT_OUTPUT;
01358 
01359   }
01360 
01361   // Check to make sure that the device is ready to receive commands
01362   do
01363   {
01364     retval = Si114xNop( si114x_handle );
01365     if( retval != 0 ) { retval = -2; goto error_exit; }
01366 
01367 
01368     response = Si114xReadFromRegister( si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE );
01369     if (response != 0)
01370     {
01371       delay_1ms();
01372     }
01373   } while( response != 0 );
01374 
01375   // Request for the calibration data
01376   retval = Si114xWriteToRegister( si114x_handle, REG_COMMAND, 0x12 );
01377   _waitUntilSleep(si114x_handle);
01378 
01379   if( retval != 0 ) { retval = -2; goto error_exit; }
01380 
01381   // Wait for the response register to increment
01382   do
01383   {
01384     response = Si114xReadFromRegister( si114x_handle, REG_RESPONSE );
01385     // If the upper nibbles are non-zero, something is wrong
01386     if( response == 0x80 )
01387     {
01388       // calibration code has not been implemented on this device
01389       // leading to command error. So, rather than returning an
01390       // error, handle the error by Nop and set ratios to -1.0
01391       // and return normally.
01392       Si114xNop( si114x_handle );
01393       retval = -3;
01394       goto error_exit;
01395     }
01396     else if( response & 0xfff0 )
01397     {
01398       // if upper nibble is anything but 0x80, exit with an error
01399       retval = -2;
01400       goto error_exit;
01401     }
01402     if (response != 1)
01403     {
01404       delay_1ms();
01405     }
01406   } while( response != 1 );
01407 
01408   // Retrieve the 12 bytes from the interface registers
01409   retval = Si114xBlockRead( si114x_handle, REG_ALS_VIS_DATA0, 12, buffer );
01410   if( retval != 0 ) { retval = -2; goto error_exit; }
01411 
01412   DEBUG_PRINT_OUTPUT;
01413 
01414   retval=si114x_get_cal_index( si114x_handle, buffer );
01415 
01416   if( retval != 0 )
01417   {
01418     retval = -2; goto error_exit;
01419   }
01420 
01421   si114x_cal->ledi_ratio       = ledi_ratio(buffer);
01422   si114x_cal->vispd_correction = vispd_correction(buffer);
01423   si114x_cal->irpd_correction  = irpd_correction(buffer);
01424   si114x_cal->adcrange_ratio   = adcrange_ratio(buffer);
01425   si114x_cal->ucoef_p          = calref[find_cal_index(buffer)].ucoef;
01426   si114x_cal->irsize_ratio     = irsize_ratio(buffer);
01427 
01428   DEBUG_PRINT_OUTPUT_2;
01429 
01430   return 0;
01431 
01432 error_exit:
01433   si114x_cal->vispd_correction = FX20_ONE;
01434   si114x_cal->irpd_correction  = FX20_ONE;
01435   si114x_cal->adcrange_ratio   = FLT_TO_FX20( 14.5 );
01436   si114x_cal->irsize_ratio     = FLT_TO_FX20(  6.0 );
01437   si114x_cal->ledi_ratio       = FX20_ONE;
01438   si114x_cal->ucoef_p          = NULL;
01439   return retval;
01440 }
01441 
01442 /***************************************************************************/
01470 int16_t si114x_set_ucoef( HANDLE        si114x_handle,
01471                           uint8_t*      input_ucoef,
01472                           SI114X_CAL_S* si114x_cal )
01473 {
01474   int8_t           response;
01475   uint8_t          temp;
01476   uint32_t         vc=FX20_ONE, ic=FX20_ONE, long_temp;
01477   struct operand_t op;
01478   uint8_t*         ref_ucoef = si114x_cal->ucoef_p;
01479   uint8_t          out_ucoef[4];
01480 
01481   if( input_ucoef != NULL ) ref_ucoef = input_ucoef;
01482 
01483   if( ref_ucoef == NULL )   return -1 ;
01484 
01485   // retrieve part identification
01486   response = Si114xReadFromRegister( si114x_handle, REG_PART_ID );
01487   switch( response )
01488   {
01489     case 0x32: case 0x45: case 0x46: case 0x47: temp = 1; break;
01490     default:                                    temp = 0; break;
01491   }
01492   if( !temp ) return -1;
01493 
01494   if(si114x_cal != 0)
01495   {
01496     if(si114x_cal->vispd_correction > 0) vc = si114x_cal->vispd_correction;
01497     if(si114x_cal->irpd_correction  > 0) ic = si114x_cal->irpd_correction;
01498   }
01499 
01500   op.op1 = ref_ucoef[0] + ((ref_ucoef[1])<<8);
01501   op.op2 = vc;
01502   long_temp   = fx20_multiply( &op );
01503   out_ucoef[0] = (long_temp & 0x00ff);
01504   out_ucoef[1] = (long_temp & 0xff00)>>8;
01505 
01506   op.op1 = ref_ucoef[2] + (ref_ucoef[3]<<8);
01507   op.op2 = ic;
01508   long_temp   = fx20_multiply( &op );
01509   out_ucoef[2] = (long_temp & 0x00ff);
01510   out_ucoef[3] = (long_temp & 0xff00)>>8;
01511 
01512   DEBUG_UCOEF
01513 
01514   response = Si114xBlockWrite( si114x_handle, REG_UCOEF0 , 4, out_ucoef);
01515 
01516   return response;
01517 }
01518 #else // INCLUDE_SI114X_CALIBRATION_CODE
01519 
01520 /********************   STUB FUNCTIONS ONLY  **********************************/
01521 
01522 int16_t si114x_get_calibration( HANDLE        si114x_handle,
01523                                 SI114X_CAL_S* si114x_cal,
01524                                 uint8_t       security)
01525 {
01526   // although the SI114x_CAL_S structure is not filled up properly, the
01527   // set_ucoef() function will not use it.
01528   return 0;
01529 }
01530 
01531 int16_t si114x_set_ucoef( HANDLE        si114x_handle,
01532                           uint8_t*      input_ucoef,
01533                           SI114X_CAL_S* si114x_cal )
01534 {
01535   int16_t response;
01536   uint8_t code ucoef[4] = { 0x7B, 0x6B, 0x01, 0x00 } ;
01537 
01538   // This will write 4 bytes starting with I2C address 0x13
01539   response = Si114xBlockWrite( si114x_handle, REG_UCOEF0, 4, &ucoef[0] );
01540   return response;
01541 }
01542 #endif // INCLUDE_SI114X_CALIBRATION_CODE
